string-array.name: lose_insults
string-array.item: I was playing with “One arm behind my back” and I still won!
But of course: my brain is much smaller than yours. Bigger ain’t always better!
That’s understandable: I can think several billion thoughts a second. Whereas you, well… keep the day job.
It’s alright to cry uncle, and ask for a hint. Then again, sometimes there’s no useful hint to be had. Or maybe Uncle just doesn’t care.
Changing levels might give you an advantage. Might. (Snicker.)
You should spend more time with books than with Android. I recommend “Winning Ways for Your Mathematical Plays”.

string-array.name: win_insults
string-array.item: I wouldn’t brag too loud, were I you. I mean, come on, I was playing with “One arm behind my back”.
Yeah, well, even a blind squirrel finds an acorn sometimes.
Made heavy use of that Hint button, dincha?
Changed the level to cheat your way to victory, dincha?
You spent so much time with “Winning Ways for Your Mathematical Plays” that you killed your social life, didn’t you?

resources.string: Start a new game, with the same settings?
The computer will always figure out the best move, if it’s available. Check this box, however, the computer will sometimes make a mistake. Sometimes.
Level 1 is easiest. Higher levels increase the number of base points. Even-numbered levels are identical to odd-numbered levels, but forbid hints.
Defines how large you want the playing board to be. Larger values require more time for the computer’s first move, or for your first hint.
